name: Hurst v. Florida
question: In light of the Supreme Court’s decision in Ring v. Arizona, does the Florida death sentencing scheme, which does not require a jury to determine whether a capital defendant is mentally retarded or to unanimously sentence a defendant to death, violate the Sixth Amendment’s jury trial guarantee or the Eighth Amendment’s prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment?
description: A case in which the Court held that Florida’s sentencing scheme violated the Sixth Amendment’s guarantee of a jury trial in light of the Supreme Court’s decision in Ring v. Arizona, which held that the Sixth Amendment required a jury to sentence the defendant to death.

name: Montgomery v. Louisiana
question:
1) Does the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision in Miller v. Alabama, which held that the Eighth Amendment prohibits mandatory sentencing schemes that require children convicted of homicide to be sentenced to life in prison without parole, apply retroactively?

(2)Does the U.S. Supreme Court have the jurisdiction to review the Louisiana Supreme Court’s determination that the Miller rule does not apply retroactively?
description: A case in which the Court held that the Supreme Court’s decision in Miller v. Alabama, which prohibits sentencing schemes that impose a punishment of mandatory life without parole for juvenile offenders convicted of homicide, applied retroactively.

name: DIRECTV, Inc. v. Imburgia
question: Did the California Court of Appeal err in holding that a reference to state law in an arbitration clause required the application of that state law despite its preemption by the Federal Arbitration Act?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Federal Arbitration Act preempted state law and required the enforcement of a contract’s arbitration agreement.

name: Montanile v. Board of Trustees of the National Elevator Industrial Health Benefit Plan
question: For purposes of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974, is a reimbursement to an employee welfare benefit plan “appropriate equitable relief” if the identified source of the reimbursement has already been spent or disbursed?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 does not allow for a suit to recover reimbursement of an asset that has been fully disbursed on non-traceable items such as services.

name: Kansas v. Carr
question:
(1) Does the Eighth Amendment require that a capital-sentencing jury be affirmatively instructed that mitigating circumstances need not be proven beyond a reasonable doubt?

(2) Does a trial court's decision not to sever the sentencing phase of a joint trial violate the defendants’ Eighth Amendment rights to an individualized sentencing determination?
description: A case in which the Court decided that the Eighth Amendment does not require that a jury be instructed that mitigating circumstances do not need to be proven beyond a reasonable doubt, nor does it require that the sentencing phase of a joint trial be severed.

name: Spokeo, Inc. v. Robins
question: Can Congress authorize a cause of action based on a violation of a federal statute and therefore confer Article III standing on a plaintiff who has not suffered concrete harm?
description: A case in which the Court held that lower courts need to consider the elements of Article III standing analysis separately in determining whether standing is sufficient for a federal court to hear the case.

name: Green v. Brennan
question: Under federal employment discrimination law, does the filing period for a constructive discharge claim begin to run at the time of the employer’s last allegedly discriminatory act?
description: A case in which the Court held that the 45-day period in which an employee must file a constructive discharge claim under federal employment discrimination law begins to run on the date the employee resigns.

name: Campbell-Ewald Company v. Gomez
question:
(1) Does a case become moot when a plaintiff receives an offer of complete relief for his claim? If so, is the answer different when the plaintiff has asserted a class action claim but receives the offer of complete relief before any class is certified?
(2) Is the doctrine of derivative sovereign immunity limited to claims arising out of property damage caused by public works projects?
description: A case in which the Court held that an unaccepted settlement offer does not make a plaintiff’s claim moot, and a federal contractor does not have derivative sovereign liability from a suit under the Telephone Consumer Protection Act.

name: Evenwel v. Abbott
question: Does the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment require that districting take into account the number of voters rather than the total population?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the “one person, one vote” principle of the Equal Protection Clause allows a state to draw its legislative districts based on total population.

name: Luis v. United States
question: <p>Does the pretrial restraint of assets that are not directly related to the crime at issue and are needed to retain counsel of choice violate the defendant’s Fifth and Sixth Amendment rights?</p>
description: A case in which the Court determined that the pretrial restraining of a defendant's assets untainted by their crime that are needed to retain counsel of choice violates the Sixth Amendment.

name: Shapiro v. McManus
question: May a single-judge district court determine that a claim governed by the Three-Judge Court Act need not be heard by a three-judge panel, not because the claim is insubstantial, but because the complaint did not state a claim under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 12(b)(6)?
description: A case in which the Court held that a claim covered by the Three-Judge Court Act must be heard by a three-judge panel.

name: Dollar General Corporation v. Mississippi Band of Choctaw Indians
question: Does a tribal court have jurisdiction to adjudicate civil tort claims against nonmembers?
description: A case in which the equally divided Court affirmed the lower court, determining a tribal court had jurisdiction to adjudicate civil tort claims against nonmembers.

name: Bruce v. Samuels
question: When a prisoner has more than one case or appeal pending in federal courts, does the Prison Litigation Reform Act cap the monthly payment to cover filing fees at 20% of the prisoner’s monthly income?
description: A case in which the Court will determine whether the Prison Litigation Reform Act caps the monthly payment to cover a prisoner’s filing fees at 20% of the prisoner’s monthly income regardless of the number of pending cases the prisoner has in federal courts.

name: Federal Energy Regulatory Commission v. Electric Power Supply Association, et al.
question:
(1) Does the Federal Power Act grant the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission the authority to regulate the rules operators of wholesale energy markets use to pay for reduction in electricity consumption?

(2) Did the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit err in holding that the rule was arbitrary and capricious?
description: A case in which the Court held that the Federal Power Act (FPA) grants the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) the authority to regulate wholesale market operators’ compensation for reduction in electricity consumption, and the rule in question was not arbitrary and capricious.

name: Fisher v. University of Texas
question: Does the University of Texas’ use of race as a consideration in the admissions process violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the University of Texas’ use of race as a consideration in the admissions process did not violate the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

name: Foster v. Chatman
question: Was there race-based discrimination of the type Batson v. Kentucky prohibits in the jury selection process of Foster’s trial?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the new evidence in this case was sufficient to establish that there was purposeful discrimination of the type that Batson v. Kentucky prohibits in the jury selection process of Foster’s trial.

name: Gobeille v. Liberty Mutual Insurance Co.
question: Do the reporting requirements of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 preempt a Vermont state statute regarding reporting requirements as applied to a self-insured employee health plan?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the reporting requirements of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) preempt a Vermont state statute regarding reporting requirements as applied to a self-insured employee health plan.

name: Friedrichs v. California Teachers Association
question:
(1) Do public-sector agency shop arrangements violate the First Amendment’s protections for freedom of speech and assembly?

(2) Does the First Amendment prohibit the practice of requiring public employees to affirmatively opt-out of subsidizing nonchargeable speech rather than to affirmatively consent?
description: A case in which the Court will determine whether the California agency shop arrangements and opt-out requirements for union relationships violate the First Amendment.

name: Harris v. Arizona Independent Redistricting Commission
question:
(1) Does the desire to gain advantage for one political party justify intentionally over-populating voting districts so that individual votes are devalued, thereby violating the one-person, one-vote principle?

(2) Does the desire to obtain favorable preclearance review from the Justice Department permit the creation of voting districts that deviate from the one-person, one-vote principle in the wake of the Supreme Court’s decision in Shelby County v. Holder?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the creation of voting districts that deviate from the “one person, one vote” principle may be justified by legitimate considerations, such as a desire to comply with the Voting Rights Act as it was in effect at the time of the plan.

name: Kingdomware Technologies, Inc. v. United States
question:
1. Is this case moot if the contracts at issue have already been performed?
  2. Is the Department of Veterans Affairs’ “set-aside,” which restricts competition to veteran-owned businesses when there is a reasonable expectation that two or more such businesses will offer reasonable bids for the contract, mandatory?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Court had jurisdiction to address the merits of the case even if the contracts had already been performed, and the Department of Veterans Affairs’ “set-aside” for veteran-owned businesses is mandatory.

name: Lockhart v. United States
question: Does the mandatory minimum for a child pornography sentence apply when the defendant has previously been convicted of “aggravated sexual abuse” or “sexual abuse,” even when the previous conviction does not involve a minor?
description: A case in which the Court determined that a prior conviction of “aggravated sexual abuse” or “sexual abuse” may trigger a mandatory minimum sentence, even when the prior conviction did not involve a minor.

name: Menominee Indian Tribe of Wisconsin v. United States
question: Did the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit properly hold that there were no extraordinary circumstances present in this case that would have prevented the statute of limitations from running?
description: A case in which the Court determined that there were no extraordinary circumstances out of the Menominee Indian Tribe’s control to toll the statute of limitations from running.

name: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc. v. Manning
question: Does the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 provide for federal jurisdiction over state law claims seeking to establish liability based on violations of the federal Act?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 creates the same test for establishing federal jurisdiction as the general test for whether a federal court has jurisdiction: Whether the case “arises under” federal law.

name: Musacchio v. United States
question:
1. Does the law of the case doctrine require the sufficiency of evidence to be measured against the elements laid out in the jury instructions when those elements require the government to prove more than the statute requires and the government did not object at trial?
  2. Is a statute of limitations defense that is not raised at trial reviewable on appeal?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the law of the case doctrine does not require that the sufficiency of evidence be measured against the elements laid out in the jury instructions when those elements require the government to prove more than the statute requires and the government did not object at trial. The Court also determined that a statute of limitations defense that is not raised at trial is not reviewable on appeal.

name: Luna Torres v. Lynch
question: Does a state offense constitute an aggravated felony for the purpose of the removal of a permanent resident when the federal statute describes the state offense but also includes an interstate commerce element that the state offense lacks?
description: A case in which the Court determined that a state offense may constitute an aggravated felony for the purpose of the removal of a permanent resident when it includes all the elements of the federal statute with the exception of the interstate commerce element.

name: Tyson Foods, Inc. v. Bouaphakeo
question:
May differences among plaintiff class members be ignored for the purpose of class certification when liability and damages will be calculated based on statistical techniques that presume all class members are identical to an average?

May a class action be certified and maintained when the class contains members who were not injured and therefore have no legal right to damages?
description: A case in which the Court determined that a class action is properly certified and maintained, despite differences among the plaintiff class, if all the individual plaintiffs' cases ask the same central question and even if some plaintiffs were not injured and have no legal right to damages.

name: OBB Personenverkehr AG v. Sachs
question:
(1) In determining whether an entity is an “agent” of a foreign state under the Foreign Sovereign Immunities Act of 1976, do common law principles of agency apply?

(2) Is a tort claim for personal injuries suffered in connection with travel outside of the United States “based upon” the sale of the ticket in the United States?
description: A case in which the Court held that the commercial activity exception to the Foreign Sovereign Immunity Act only applies when the suit is based upon activity that took place in the United States, and it was not sufficient to establish a single element of the claim in question.

name: Hawkins v. Community Bank of Raymore
question:
(1) Are the spousal guarantors of loans considered “applicants” for the purposes of gaining the protections of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act, even though they were not an integral part of the credit transaction?

(2) Does the Federal Reserve Board have the authority under the Equal Credit Opportunity Act to create regulations that include spousal guarantors as “applicants” for the purposes of eliminating discrimination against married women?
description: A case in which an equally-divided Court affirmed the lower court in that spousal guarantors could not be considered “applicants” for the purposes of the protections the Equal Credit Opportunity Act provides.

name: Ocasio v. United States
question: Does a conspiracy to commit extortion require that the conspirators agree to extort money or property from a third party outside of the conspiracy?
description: A case in which the Court determined that a conspiracy to commit extortion can involve the purported victims of the extortion as members of the conspiracy.

name: Wittman v. Personhuballah
question: Do the appellants have standing to appeal this case to the U.S. Supreme Court under Article III of the U.S. Constitution?
description: A case in which the Court determined that members of Congress whose chances of reelection might be impaired by a new districting plan did not have standing under Article III of the U.S. Constitution to appeal their case to the Supreme Court.

name: Taylor v. United States
question: In a federal criminal prosecution under the Hobbs Act, is the government required to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that the robbery of a drug dealer is an inherent economic enterprise that satisfies the interstate commerce element of the offense?
description: A case in which the Court determined that, in a prosecution for robbery under the Hobbs Act, the commerce element is satisfied when the government shows that the defendant robbed a drug dealer of drugs or drug proceeds.

name: Molina-Martinez v. United States
question: When an error in the application of the U.S. Sentencing Guidelines results in the application of the wrong Guideline range to the defendant, should the appellate court presume that the error affected the defendant’s substantial rights?
description: A case in which the Court held that an error in the application of the U.S. Sentencing Guidelines that results in the wrong Guideline range affected the defendant’s substantial rights.

name: RJR Nabisco v. The European Community
question: Can the Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organizations (RICO) statute apply extraterritorially?
description: A case in which the Court held that some sections of the Racketeer Influenced Corrupt Organizations (RICO) statute can apply extraterritorially because Congress clearly based them on predicate offenses that can occur outside of the United States.

name: Duncan v. Owens
question: Can habeas relief be awarded in the absence of clearly established precedent that the inference of motive at trial violates the defendant’s right to due process?
description: A case in which the Court will determine whether habeas relief can be awarded in the absence of clearly established precedent that the inference of motive at trial violates the defendant’s right to due process.

name: MHN Government Services, Inc., and Managed Health Network, Inc. v. Zaborowski, et al.
question: Is an arbitration clause in an employment contract that has been held to be unconscionable still enforceable?
description: A case in which the Court will determine whether an unconscionable arbitration clause in a contract is enforceable.

name: Utah v. Strieff
question: Should evidence seized incident to a lawful arrest on an outstanding warrant be suppressed because the warrant was discovered during an investigatory stop later found to be unlawful?
description: A case in which the Court determined that, in the absence of flagrant police misconduct, the discovery of a valid, pre-existing, and untainted arrest warrant attenuated the connection between the unconstitutional investigatory stop and the evidence seized incident to the lawful arrest.

name: Americold Realty Trust v. Conagra Foods, Inc., et al.
question: Is the citizenship of a trust for the purposes of diversity jurisdiction based on the diversity of the trust’s beneficiaries as well as the trustees?
description: A case in which the Court determined that, for the purposes of diversity jurisdiction, the citizenship of a trust is based on the citizenship of its members, which includes the beneficiaries as well as the trustees.

name: Nebraska v. Parker
question: Did the passage of the 1882 Act diminish the original boundaries of the Omaha Indian Reservation?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the passage of the 1882 Act by Congress did not diminish the original boundaries of the Omaha Indian Reservation.

name: Bank Markazi v. Peterson
question: Does a statute that effectively directs a particular result in a single pending case violate the separation of powers?
description: A case in which the Court decided that a statute effectively directing a particular result in a single pending case does not violate the separation of powers.

name: Sturgeon v. Frost
question: Does the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act of 1980 prohibit the National Park Service from exercising regulatory control over state, Native, corporate, and private Alaska land physically located within the boundaries of the National Park System?
description: A case in which the Court held that the Alaska National Interest Lands Conservation Act of 1980 did not allow the National Park Service to regulate all land physically within the boundaries of the National Park System in Alaska.

name: Heffernan v. City of Paterson
question: Does the First Amendment prohibit the government from demoting a public employee based on a supervisor’s perception that the employee supports a political candidate?
description: A case in which the Court determined that a government employee who is demoted because of perceived involvement in protected political activity is entitled to challenge his demotion under the First Amendment, even if the demotion was based on a factual mistake.

name: Williams v. Pennsylvania
question:
Are the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments violated when a state supreme court justice declines to recuse himself from a capital case in which he was the district attorney who approved the decision to seek the death penalty?

Are the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments violated by the participation of a potentially biased jurist in a multi-member tribunal in a capital case, regardless of whether that jurist’s vote is ultimately decisive?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments are violated when a judge who was previously involved in the case as a prosecutor declines to recuse himself, regardless of whether that judge’s decision as part of a multi-member tribunal was dispositive.

name: Maryland v. Kulbicki
question: Did the Maryland Court of Appeals properly vacate Kulbicki’s conviction on the grounds that he received ineffective assistance of counsel because his attorneys failed to question the legitimacy of the ballistics evidence presented against him?
description: A case in which the Court held that the Maryland Court of Appeals impermissibly vacated a conviction based on a claim of ineffective assistance of counsel for failing to question ballistics evidence that was considered valid at the time of the conviction.

name: Puerto Rico v. Sanchez Valle
question: Are the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico and the U.S. federal government separate sovereigns for the purpose of double jeopardy?
description: A case in which the Court held that Puerto Rico and the U.S. federal government are the same sovereign entity for the purpose of the Double Jeopardy Clause.

name: Hughes v. Talen Energy Marketing, LLC
question: Does the Federal Power Act preempt attempted state regulation of utility contracts and sales?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Federal Power Act preempted state regulation of utility contracts and sales.

name: Halo Electronics v. Pulse Electronics Inc.
question: Did the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit err by applying a rigid, two-part test for enhancing patent infringement damages under 35 U.S.C §284?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the rigid two-part test is not necessary for determining whether a patentee is eligible for enhanced damages under 35 U.S.C §284.

name: Franchise Tax Board of California v. Hyatt
question:
(1) Can Nevada refuse to extend to other states haled into Nevada courts the same immunities Nevada receives in those courts?

(2) Should Nevada v. Hall, a case in which the Supreme Court held that a state could be haled into the court of another state without its consent, be overruled?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Constitution does not allow Nevada to refuse to extend to other states haled into Nevada courts the same immunities Nevada would receive in those courts.

name: Voisine v. United States
question: Does a misdemeanor crime that requires only a showing of recklessness qualify as a misdemeanor crime of domestic violence under federal statutes 18 U.S.C. §§ 921(a)(33)(A) and 922(g)(9)?
description: A case in which the Court held that a reckless domestic violence assault qualifies as misdemeanor crime of domestic violence for the purpose of prohibiting firearm possession.

name: Nichols v. United States
question: Is a convicted sexual offender required to update his residency under the Sex Offender Registration and Notification Act if he moves outside of U.S. jurisdiction?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Sexual Offender Registration and Notification Act does not require a sex offender who is moving to a country outside of U.S. jurisdiction to update his residence with the sexual offender registry.

name: Mullenix v. Luna
question: Did the district court and the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit err in determining that Chadrin Lee Mullenix was not entitled to qualified immunity?
description: A case in which the Court determined that a trooper was entitled to qualified immunity for his actions in the context of the situation he faced.

name: Husky Electronics v. Ritz
question: Is fraudulently transferring money to avoid repayment of a debt considered false representation under bankruptcy statute 11 U.S.C. §523(a)(2)(A) to prevent discharge of the debt?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the “actual fraud” language of the bankruptcy statute encompasses traditional forms of fraud and is not limited to fraudulent representation.

name: Zubik v. Burwell
question:
(1) Does the availability of a regulatory exemption for religious employers regarding the Affordable Care Act’s contraceptive mandate eliminate the substantial burden on those organizations’ exercise of their religious freedom?

(2) Do the Department of Health and Human Services’ guidelines satisfy the Religious Freedom Restoration Act’s demanding test for overriding religious objections?

(3) Do the Department of Health and Human Services’ guidelines violate the Religious Freedom Restoration Act when the government has not proven that the guidelines are the least restrictive means of advancing the compelling government interest?
description: A case in which the Court determined that insurance companies could potentially provide contraceptive coverage to employees of organizations that object to such coverage on religious grounds without the organizations needing to provide notification.

name: Whole Woman’s Health v. Hellerstedt
question: Should a court's "substantial burden" analysis take into account the extent to which laws that restrict access to abortion services actually serve the government's stated interest in promoting health?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the regulations at issue unconstitutionally imposed an undue burden on women seeking abortions because they created a substantial burden and did not actually serve the stated government interest.

name: Simmons v. Himmelreich
question: Does the judgment bar in 28 U.S.C. §2676 of the Federal Torts Claims Act (FTCA) prohibit an action brought against government agents if the claim brought under the FTCA was dismissed?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the judgment bar of the Federal Tort Claims Act (FTCA) does not apply to claims dismissed for falling under the exceptions to the FTCA.

name: Betterman v. Montana
question: Is it a violation of the Sixth Amendment right to a speedy trial to postpone sentencing for fourteen months after a guilty plea has been issued?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Sixth Amendment’s guarantee of a speedy trial does not extend past a guilty verdict or guilty plea.

name: Puerto Rico v. Franklin California Tax-Free Trust
question: Does Chapter 9 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, which doesn’t apply to Puerto Rico, nonetheless preempt the Puerto Rico statute that created a mechanism for public utilities to restructure their debts?
description: A case in which the Court determined that Chapter 9 of the Bankruptcy Code preempted the Puerto Rico statute that allowed public utilities to restructure their debt.

name: Universal Health Services, Inc. v. Escobar
question:
(1) Is the implied certification test for determining when claims have sufficiently pled falsity for the purposes of the False Claims Act valid?

(2) If so, does the relevant statute need to explicitly state the conditions of payment with which the defendant allegedly failed to comply?
description: A case in which the Court held that the implied certification test could be a valid basis for False Claims Act liability, and the conditions of payment with which the defendant allegedly failed to comply did not need to be explicitly stated.

name: CRST Van Expedited v. EEOC
question: Is a fee award available after the dismissal of a case for failure to satisfy pre-suit obligations?
description: A case in which the Court determined that a defendant may be a “prevailing party” for the purpose of the award of fees even without a ruling on the merits.

name: Sheriff v. Gillie
question:
1. Are special counsel appointed by the state Attorney General to collect debts are “state officers” under the meaning of the Federal Debt Collection Practices Act?
  2. Is it materially misleading for special counsel to use Attorney General letterhead to convey that they are collecting debts owed to the state on the Attorney General’s behalf?
description: A case in which the Court held that, regardless of whether special counsel appointed by the Attorney General to collect debts are “state officers” under the Federal Debt Collection Practices Act, the use of Attorney General letterhead by such special counsel is not materially misleading.

name: Ross v. Blake
question: Is there a "special circumstances" exception to the Prison Litigation Reform Act’s requirement to exhaust administrative remedies when the inmate erroneously believes that he satisfied the requirement by participating in an internal investigation?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Prison Litigation Reform Act’s requirement to exhaust administrative remedies does not have a “special circumstances” exception.

name: White v. Wheeler
question: Was the decision to strike a potential juror based on that juror’s equivocal statements about his ability to consider the death penalty a reasonable application of the Supreme Court’s precedence as established in Witherspoon v. Illinois?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the decision to strike a potential juror based on that juror’s equivocal statements about his ability to consider the death penalty was a reasonable application of Supreme Court precedent.

name: Birchfield v. North Dakota
question: In the absence of a warrant, may a state statute criminalize an individual’s refusal to submit to a blood alcohol test?
description: A case in which the Court determined that warrantless blood tests incident to an arrest for drunk driving violate the Fourth Amendment, but warrantless breath tests incident to an arrest for drunk driving do not.

name: United States Army Corps of Engineers v. Hawkes Co., Inc.
question: Is the Army Corps of Engineers’ determination that the property constitutes “water of the United States” a final agency action subject to judicial review under the Administrative Procedure Act?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Army Corps of Engineers’ jurisdictional determination that a property constituted “water of the United States” was a final agency action subject to judicial review under the Administrative Procedure Act.

name: United States v. Bryant
question: Does an uncounseled conviction in tribal court used to satisfy the predicate offense requirement of 18 U.S.C. 117(a), which criminalizes domestic assault by a person who has been convicted of at least two domestic violence offenses in federal, state, or tribal court, violate the Sixth Amendment?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the use of an uncounseled conviction in tribal court proceedings that complied with the Indian Civil Rights Act of 1968 (ICRA) as a predicate offense under 18 U.S.C. 117(a) did not violate the Sixth Amendment.

name: Kirtsaeng v. John Wiley & Sons
question: What constitutes the appropriate standard for awarding attorneys’ fees to a prevailing party under Section 505 of the Copyright Act?
description: A case in which the Court determined that, when deciding whether to grant attorney’s fees under Section 505 of the Copyright Act, courts should give substantial weight to the objective reasonableness of the losing party’s position, but that determination should not be the controlling factor.

name: Dietz v. Bouldin
question: Can the judge recall jurors for further service in the same case after the judge has discharged a jury from service and the jurors have left the judge’s presence?
description: A case in which the Court determined that a federal district court judge has some ability to recall jurors in a civil case after identifying an error in their verdict, subject to certain limitations to ensure the jurors were not prejudiced.

name: United States v. Texas
question:
1. Do states that provide subsidies to persons who are granted deferred action have standing to sue because the new guidelines will lead to more persons being eligible for deferred action?
  2. Is the Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA) program arbitrary and capricious?
  3. Did DAPA violate the Administrative Procedure Act by failing to go through the notice-and-comment procedure?
  4. Does DAPA violate the Take Care Clause of the Constitution?
description: A case in which the equally divided Court affirmed the lower court's judgment that the Deferred Action for Parents of Americans and Lawful Permanent Residents (DAPA) program was arbitrary and capricious, and failed to undergo notice-and-comment procedures as required by the Administrative Procedure Act.

name: Encino Motorcars v. Navarro
question: Are “service advisors” employed at a car dealership exempt from overtime compensation under the Fair Labor Standards Act?
description: A case in which the Court held that, because the Department of Labor did not give adequate reasons for altering its position on whether service advisors are exempt from overtime compensation under the Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA), the case should be remanded for reinterpretation that does not give controlling weight to the Department’s 2011 position.

name: Cuozzo Speed Technologies v. Lee
question:
1. May the Patent Trial and Appeal Board apply the broadest reasonable interpretation of patent claims during an inter partes review proceeding?
  2. Is the Patent Trial and Appeal Board’s use of inter partes review judicially reviewable?
description: A case in which the Court held that the Patent Trial and Appeal Board may apply the broadest reasonable interpretation of patent claims during an inter partes review proceeding, and such a proceeding is not judicially reviewable.

name: McDonnell v. United States
question: For the purpose of federal bribery statutes, is an “official action” limited to the exercise or threatened exercise of actual governmental power, and if the term is not limited in this manner, are the statutes unconstitutional?
description: A case in which the Court held that, for the purpose of federal bribery statutes, an “official act” is a decision or action on a question, matter, cause, suit, proceeding, or controversy that involves a specific exercise of formal governmental power.

name: Mathis v. United States
question: Does a predicate prior conviction under the Armed Career Criminal Act qualify when the courts examine the specific elements of the offenses in question using a modified categorical approach?
description: A case in which the Court determined that a state crime cannot qualify as a predicate offense under the Armed Career Criminal Act (ACCA) if the elements of the state offense are broader than those of a listed generic offense based on an “elements-only inquiry,” not a modified categorical approach.

name: James v. City of Boise
question: Does the Supreme Court’s decision in Hughes v. Rowe bind state courts, or does the U.S. Supreme Court lack the authority to limit the discretion of state courts where such limitation is not contained in the statute?
description: A case in which the Court held that the Idaho Supreme Court erred by concluding that the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision in Hughes v. Rowe did not bind state courts.

name: Amgen, Inc. v. Harris
question: Did the plaintiffs in this case “plausibly allege” a breach of the duty of prudence?
description: A case in which the Court held that the court of appeals erred in failing to assess whether the complaint “plausibly alleged” a breach of the duty of prudence under the standard the Court established in Fifth Third v. Dudenhoeffer.

name: Welch v. United States
question: Does the rule the Supreme Court announced in Johnson v. United States regarding what constitutes a violent offense apply retroactively?
description: A case in which the Court held that the rule the Supreme Court announced in Johnson v. United States regarding what constitutes a violent offense for the purposes of sentencing under the Armed Career Criminal Act applies retroactively.

name: V.L. v. E.L.
question: Does the Full Faith and Credit Clause of the Constitution require that the Alabama state courts recognize a Georgia state court’s adoption order?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the Full Faith and Credit Clause of the Constitution requires the Alabama state courts to recognize a Georgia state court’s adoption order.

name: Wearry v. Cain
question: To prevail on a claim that suppression of evidence violated his due process rights under Brady v. Maryland, does a defendant need to show that, more likely than not, he would have been acquitted if the suppressed evidence in question had been made available to him?
description: A case in which the Court held that, to prevail on a claim that suppression of evidence violated his due process rights, a defendant need only show that the suppressed evidence was sufficient to undermine confidence in the verdict.

name: Caetano v. Massachusetts
question: Does the Second Amendment protect the right to possess a stun gun for self-defense?
description: A case in which the Court held the lower court erred in concluding that stun guns are not afforded Second Amendment protections.

name: Woods v. Etherton
question: Did the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit properly apply the standard from the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act (AEDPA) that, as long as “fairminded jurists” could disagree about the state court’s conclusion, a federal court should not overrule a state court’s denial of habeas relief?
description: A case in which the Court held that the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act (AEDPA) requires that a federal court not overrule a state court’s denial of habeas relief as long as a “fairminded jurist” could have concluded that the state court’s denial of relief was valid.

name: Kernan v. Hinojosa
question: Does the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act’s deferential standard of review of state habeas decisions apply when the decision to deny habeas in state court was not made on the merits of the case?
description: A case in which the Court determined that that the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act’s deferential standard of review applies when the initial state court’s denial of habeas is affirmed by higher state courts, even in the form of denying consideration of the petition.

name: Lynch v. Arizona
question: When the only alternative to the death penalty is life imprisonment without the possibility of parole and the defendant’s future dangerousness has been raised as an issue, does the failure to inform the jury of a capital defendant’s ineligibility for parole violate the defendant’s due process rights?
description: A case in which the Court determined that, when the only alternative to the death penalty is life imprisonment without the possibility of parole and the defendant’s future dangerousness has been raised as an issue, the failure to inform the jury of a capital defendant’s ineligibility for parole violated the defendant’s due process rights.

name: Johnson v. Lee
question: Is evidence that there are times when a procedural bar was not used in cases in which it could have been applied sufficient to show that the bar is not adequate?
description: A case in which the Court determined that the California procedural bar in question was both firmly established and regularly followed and was therefore adequate.
